text: [Music]
hundreds have been killed in months of
protests in Nicaragua which explains why
this roundabout is covered with crosses
they represent the first victims many of
them students most of them unarmed it
all started by suddenly on April 18th a
small protest against pension reform was
attacked by supporters of President
Daniel Ortega the images of pensioners
and students being beaten up brought
more people to the streets when it
turned deadly hundreds of thousands
joined in to demand justice and the
removal of mr. Ortega many more have
dies in these crosses were planted
according to some estimates 350 in just
the first three months the killings also
unleashed a wider anger at the way the
country has been run and this metal
trees and there are hundreds of them
over the city became a symbol of it they
are a pet project of presidents Ortegas
wife who also happens to be his vice
president his critics accuse mr. Ortega
of running the country like a corrupt
family business and that he will do
anything to establish a dynasty of his
own he says the protests are accrued and
that protesters want to do with his
democratically elected government what
they have done with many of his wives
metal trays the barricades made with
these cobblestones are another important
symbol of the revolt a symbol of
physical resistance but also a powerful
echo from the past the 1979 revolution
that first brought mr. Ortega to power
use this exact same cold stones in
exactly the same way to fight against
Anastasio Somoza the last of the brutal
dynasty rule Nicaragua for more than 40
years for many the fact that the
protesters felt they needed them to
protect themselves against the crackdown
ordered by mr. Ortega proves his slowly
becoming the very same thing he once
fought against
a big difference with 1979 however is
that the current president is not facing
I'm guerrillas but mostly youngsters
armed with this homemade mortars that
are no match for the military-grade
weapons used by the government and its
supporters this explains why even though
there have been deaths on both sides the
vast majority of them have been
protesters mr. Ortegas government has
been widely condemned for using lethal
force including paramilitaries it has
also been accused of allowing
extrajudicial killings disappearances
even torture now to our final symbol
damask ones like this have been worn by
many protesters including at this rally
fittingly they come from Al Gore
Wednesday an old play about fooling the
colonial authorities the Sandinistas
also used them back in 1979 and they
have always been a symbol of resistance
against state repression but lately they
have been replaced by a far more
sinister side the balaclavas used by mr.
teca's paramilitaries as they go about
getting rid of the barricades and
hunting down the protesters for many
they bring back memories of Latin
American death squads making them feared
a Nicaragua might be moving to an even
darker place
